title: Will Jacob Zuma cease to be president of South Africa before 1 January 2017?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The man has all but survived the year.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Time is passing and the deadline is looming yet Zuma is still firmly in place.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Only if he dies of natural causes in office by that date. There is insufficient political opposition to oust him before then.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Down 2% since lightning is not likely to strike.
More confidence in last justification, downward trend, and closing window.

Affirming at 1 despite rumblings within ANC leadership committee on word of weakness of support for no-confidence motion. He appears almost certain to survive this push, and if he does , there probably won't be another one in the next few weeks.

Diffusion of responsibility if by secret ballot, wishful thinking (that the ANC can do fine with 2 more years of Zuma), infighting between ANC members, corruption, and pressure for party loyalists. Zuma will be questioned on Dec 3rd, but everything could be deferred. until next on account of the holidays. ANC could face increased pressure from the public and still hold non-consequential votes.
Down 3% since he survived the vote. Keeping it just above the consensus considering the likely/possible downgrading of debt.

Up 20% on this news: http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/anc-meeting-extended-zumas-fate-uncertain-2093875
http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-28-the-endgame-zuma-on-the-ropes-as-anc-tactical-manoeuvre-unfolds/#.WDvDP9R97iw
Zuma will fight back, of course, and getting rid of this lame duck president and his entourage won't be without problems, but it's Belshazzar's Feast time, I suspect. http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-27-analysis-should-zuma-lose-the-dominoes-would-fall/#.WDu-sNR97iw

Reduced because of the march of time. 
Even so, the pressure remains - http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/anc-turns-on-zuma-20161126
Zuma, on the other hand, has more lives than a cat, dodging every bullet directed at him.

"President Jacob Zuma’s future as ANC president was left hanging by a thread after Tourism Minister Derek Hanekom stunned Zuma and his backers when he tabled a motion for him to step down at the national executive committee (NEC) meeting yesterday." http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/anc-turns-on-zuma-20161126
The interesting part is that there is lobbying for a secret ballot, which could spell doom for Teflon Jake as there would be less fear of backlash. Without the closed shop vote, dozens of members will conveniently absent themselves - as happened with the most recent no-confidence motion - but they might show up if they can vote without reprisals.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

http://www.newsweek.com/jacob-zuma-south-africa-president-survive-anc-voters-522723?rx=us "It was a familiar scene. On November 10, South African opposition leader Mmusi Maimane stood before a rowdy Parliament in Cape Town and argued that President Jacob Zuma should leave office. For the third time this year, Maimane appealed to members of the African National Congress, the ruling party, to support a vote against their leader. . . .  As expected, Zuma easily survived the motion ; the ANC has a clear majority in Parliament, and though many party veterans have called for him to step down, ANC lawmakers supported their leader in the vote. “The motions by the DA have become ritualistic practices founded on spurious allegations and narrow political motives,” the office of the ANC’s chief whip, Jackson Mthembu, said in a statement issued before the vote. . . . 
" . . .  the ANC is still struggling to fulfill many of the promises of a free South Africa . . . Though it is still firmly in power, a string of corruption scandals dogging the Zuma administration has chipped away at its support. " . . .  It is hard to see a way forward from the current political mess, especially after the government’s anti-corruption watchdog released a report on November 2 ordering an inquiry into corruption allegations against the president and others.  "Many see Zuma’s political survival as a depressing symptom of the failed promise of the post-apartheid ANC government. In December 2015, the currency tanked after Zuma replaced his finance minister twice in a few days, widely seen as a clumsy attempt to exert control over the National Treasury. In March, the country’s highest court ruled that Zuma failed to uphold the constitution by refusing to repay some of the $23 million in public funds spent on upgrades to his private estate, including a swimming pool. He has since apologized and, abiding by a court order, paid back the money. But, in April, another court ruled that he should face nearly 800 charges of corruption that had previously been dropped, a ruling that Zuma has appealed. "Then, in local elections in August, the ANC suffered its worst-ever electoral setback; it lost its majority in three of the country’s biggest cities and won less than 60 percent of the national vote for the first time since coming to power in 1994—a performance many blamed on the president. "The pressure on Zuma intensified in the first week of November, when thousands of protesters took to the streets in the capital, Pretoria, to call for his resignation, after he asked a court to block the release of the watchdog’s report on fresh corruption allegations against him. Zuma withdrew the request, and the report was released, but the mood was ugly  . . . On November 15, after losing his attempt to pass a motion of no confidence, Maimane submitted an affidavit to police requesting they investigate “possible criminal offences” committed by Zuma and others mentioned in the report. " . . .  Since Zuma came to power in 2009, allegations of cronyism have led to a decline in his popularity; according to a March poll from research company Ipsos, nearly two-thirds of those polled think the country is going in the wrong direction. Today, more than a quarter of the population is unemployed. Inequality continues to be a drag on the economy and a stain on society, with the black majority earning far less income on average and suffering from much higher rates of poverty than the white minority. ". . . .ANC leaders promised greater introspection after its historic loss in the local elections, but conflicts within the party over Zuma have become starker. In October, 101 party veterans penned an open letter airing their concerns over the ANC’s direction. "Those seeking Zuma’s removal will face resistance from members of the ANC leadership who have a vested interest in keeping Zuma in office . . . those party members are entangled in the same patronage networks that Zuma has been accused of perpetuating. “They cannot act against him because they would also be vulnerable,” . . . . “Once you remove the head, the network becomes exposed.” "For now, Zuma probably has the numbers he needs to survive, at least in the short term. The ANC members pushing behind the scenes for a leadership change need to wait until they have a comfortable majority within the party to make their move, . . . “They’re not going to play that hand until it’s safe to do so.” "The other problem for would-be challengers within the party is that the ANC also has yet to settle on a successor. . . .  "Zuma’s critics inside the party say the nation can’t wait two years. The longer Zuma is the face of the ANC, the more its image suffers. “There is not a day that goes by without a bad Zuma story,” says Susan Booysen, a professor at Wits University in Johannesburg. “It’s doing huge damage to the ANC.” "Zuma is not immune to the mounting pressure. At a recent ANC event in KwaZulu-Natal province, a traditional stronghold for him, the president vented his anger at fellow party members for their public criticism and said he wasn’t scared of going back to prison—a fate suggested by one opposition leader—after having served 10 years at the infamous Robben Island during apartheid. “He’s very aware of what’s happening,” says Naidoo. “Is he necessarily going to act on it? He’s a renowned fighter. But those who are lining up behind him are reducing in number.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  A personal friend of mine for over 50 yrs who lives in SA has told me basically what is reported here:  "Those seeking Zuma’s removal will face resistance from members of the ANC leadership who have a vested interest in keeping Zuma in office . . . those party members are entangled in the same patronage networks that Zuma has been accused of perpetuating. “They cannot act against him because they would also be vulnerable,” and that " the ANC also has yet to settle on a successor". Reducing forecast
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

South Africa's Jacob Zuma defeats no-confidence vote in parliament
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/south-africas-jacob-zuma-defeats-no-confidence-vote-in-parliament/articleshow/55359293.cms No one can touch Teflon Zuma.
He won the vote of No Confidence convincingly
Down 25% to be closer to the consensus for awhile.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
He faces another vote of no confidence in the next weeks. He might well loose given the recent corruption report release

One could venture to say that the local grroundswell that "Zuma must resign" is  also being facilitated by non SAF interests who are  meddling in the internal affairs of a soverign nation.  The Mandela Foundation is a major local actor. But remember that Mandela was longtime CIA and Kremlin asset and Zuma had his back.m  An article link here from FT in London https://www.ft.com/content/d9e72242-a1e1-11e6-82c3-4351ce86813f reminds that "the succession to Mr Zuma is not meant to be officially settled until an ANC conference scheduled for December 2017. "  A "surprise" resignation before 1 Jan 2017 would create too much local and regional instability in what is billed as "Africa's most industrialized" economy.

No change to forecast. Just trying to wrap my head around the latest developments.
Madonsela report paints a grim picture for Zupta and his cronies: http://qz.com/825789/state-capture-jacob-zuma-the-guptas-and-corruption-in-south-africa/ But, as the former Public Protector has said, she "should have been harder on Zuma", and her released findings leave some wiggle room for the accused.
Vote of no-confidence tabled for Nov 10: http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-11-03-explainer-misconceptions-about-a-no-confidence-vote/#.WB53yNR97iw It's the third this year, and as the vote will be open rather than secret there's no great confidence that Zuma will be asked to resign.
However, ANC chief whip Jackson Mthembu's call for the entire NEC to step down is resounding: https://www.enca.com/south-africa/anc-nec-called-to-resign If Gordhan supporter CyrilRamaphosa can be emboldened to vote against his boss - possibly a good political move - this could be a done deal.
Assuming, though, that the no-confidence motion fails, the next week or two may decide this question one way or another. The next step is a judicial inquiry scheduled for early December, during which a lot of dirty laundry will be aired. It's just possible that more than a few stalwarts may see this as cancerous for the ANC and quietly urge Zuma to resign with what's left of his dignity.

According to a report on BBC Newshour yesterday, there is increasing pressure for him to step down because of the corruption scandal involving Ajay Gupta and his family, as detailed in the report "State Capture," (http://qz.com/825789/state-capture-jacob-zuma-the-guptas-and-corruption-in-south-africa/)
Jumping up to 33 percent on no-confidence vote planned for Nov 11.  Will watch politics ahead of vote to consider further increases, and will drop to 1 if he survives that vote.

The bad news is piling up at an alarming rate. In the past week alone, Zuma has lost out on the Gordhan charges and the State Capture report, The Nelson Mandela Foundation and unions representing half a million workers have called for his resignation, and thousands of protesters have clashed with police in Pretoria. The editorial cartoonists of SA are also having their say: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/02/protests-in-pretoria-as-south-africans-call-for-jacob-zuma-to-resign
According to Prince Mashele, a political analyst at Pretoria-based Centre for Politics and Research, "“I will be surprised if Zuma were to survive until January,” http://www.fin24.com/Economy/zuma-days-are-numbered-as-crisis-deepens-20161102 The same article does warn, however, that "hounding him out of office is easier said than done.”
I know the consensus on this question is very low, but Zuma is dead in the water. The only real questions are: Will he jump, or will he be pushed? And will either of those things happen before the end of the year?

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37845606
Nothing will happen, just as it has been with dizzying regularity right along.  The ANC has nobody special waiting in the wings just yet. It will take a while to groom a successor, which these days should probably entail shredding everybody's records and blowing up everybody's mobile 'phones and computers.  It is disheartening to realize that nobody learned anything from Richard Nixon's failure to destroy the tapes.

BBC (and others) report Mandela foundation demanding ouster of Zuma now is a classic example of what Lippmann and Chomsky called manufactured/manufacturing opinion link here http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37833372  but not likely to happen before close of this forecasting problem.

Time marches on.
Yet the battle rages on and there remains a strong chance the Zuma presidency will end prematurely.
Trumped up charges against Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan were withdrawn this morning in a blow to the Zuma camp.

http://www.rdm.co.za/politics/2016/10/26/politics-live-anc-leadership-quashed-rebellion-against-zuma

Back up to 2:1 in light of recent events. Zuma's Gordhan/Gupta dilemma has real potential to unravel his presidency, and with two months to go the timeline for a recall or resignation is still feasible. http://www.fin24.com/BizNews/how-world-sees-sa-zuma-now-increasingly-vulnerable-after-latest-bombshells-20161018
Zuma remains a wily customer, however, and getting rid of him won't be easy. I thought his recent comments about SA democracy were very interesting: http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/tell-the-world-its-democracy-zuma-to-ambassadors-20161018
Is it too much to hope that this indicates he has seen the writing on the wall? In a broader context, a Zuma resignation would have an enormous impact on what passes for democracy in Africa. Consensus is so low on this question because African presidents - Nkurunziza, Kabila, Jammeh, Mugabe, dos Santos, Idriss Deby, Afwerki etc etc - don't resign, no matter what. Zuma has the chance to make a real statement here, but will he?

Disrupting the momentum of his enemies, Team Zuma moves from one court to another, and it all buys time, link here http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/its-not-over-yet-for-zuma-20161008 South Africa regaining the slot as the "second largest" economy on Africa continent (outpacing Egypt) link here http://abokifx.com/south-africa-reclaims-spot-africas-second-biggest-economy-business-tech/    helps solidify Zuma's reputation since booting him from office would likely trigger economic turmoil

This is just my initial guess, so I attach low confidence. I have been following the situation there, but have not been trying to estimate the odds before now. There are many factors to consider, but the timing is very important to me. There is no momentum to remove Zuma right now, despite the many problems (falling Rand, uni student protests demanding free education, minimum wage debates, unrest leading to vandalism, etc). The most volatile part of the situation is his problems working with Gordhan. If he does force Gordhan out before Jan '17 then this could be enough tension (via the impact on the Rand and state borrowing costs) to push the ANC to act. Everything in SA takes much longer than you expect, though, so it seems very unlikely to be possible before the end of 2016.

The endgame is in play. 
The National Prosecuting Authority is proceeding against Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan with trumped-up charges relating to his tenure as head of SARS (SA Revenue Services).
This is a high-stakes stand-off.

I have a very astute African friend in South Africa. The fact the public protector has decided the president will have to answer investigative questions under oath sends a signal that the president is in serious trouble. And if it emerges that he was running the country under the dictates of the Guptas, as it has widely been alleged, then l can see his days being numbered. His aides may not be able to protect him any further. There one thing l trust about South Africa, the judiciary is very strong and unwavering.

Sweeping radical party reform proposals, whether in themselves laudatory or not, seem to be more of a distraction than something that might be sufficient to unseat Zuma. It seems to me that given the recalcitrant nature of Zuma, either a split within the ANC ruling body (a renegade group) or wholesale withdrawal of cooperation with the ANC by society generally (grinding the economy to halt) are the two most effective strategies to remove Zuma. Left up to himself, Zuma will not resign, the ANC leadership will also not spontaneously offer up a mea culpa and resign; and any proposal that calls for such is more of a hindrance than a help to the goal of removing Zuma. To date, there are no ANC leadership renegades (or any bloc of such renegades) nor is there any news of general civil strikes or other manifestations of withdrawal of support intended to force the issue to a short term resolution.
http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/the-seven-sins-the-anc-must-fix-to-survive-20160924

ANC must save SA from becoming ‘mafia state’, urges Mantashe
http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2016/09/22/head-to-head-with-zuma-anc-must-save-sa-from-becoming-mafia-state-urges-mantashe/ When someone says "mafia state," they are referring to the way an organization is structured and operates. It has certain identifiable characteristics. Since having started in this GJ exercise, it's hard not to say that many of the subject states evidence these structures.  Yet, the funny thing is, the victims in these states, and most observers, seem to think and act as though such corrupt governments arise spontaneously and independently within their own countries. They are missing the broader pattern. Global governance, as practiced today, is a highly corrupt machine, optimized for kleptocracy. Heck, how many "full service" institutions such as Mossack Fonseca does one need to see before realizing that governmental corruption is nurtured and cultivated in a highly organized fashion. Do you think that Dictator A just looks in the Yellow Pages to find international banking havens and offshore investment opportunities? Of course not. These opportunities and structures are delivered to him/her. The citizens of South Africa and, for example, Brazil, are not fighting separate phenomena. They are battling different aspects of the very same phenomenon. "it's time we're aware, it's a small world after all"

Tsunami about to hit Jacob Zuma 
http://www.citizen.co.za/1291471/tsunami-about-to-hit-jacob-zuma/  Loss of key Zuma confederates and risk of adverse legal decisions. Only problem, the time horizon is the 2019 election. I do like the notion that the columnist is willing to stake some personal credibility on his prediction. Isn't that what we should expect? The columnist is promoting an implicit claim that he is a better observer of political reality than the average person, and that his reports of his observations are reliable. There should be a way to verify such implicit claims, or at least, as the author himself volunteers, for such claimants to put some skin in the game (albeit it's a linguistic bet only).

Scopa blasts Anti-Corruption Task Team (+1)
http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/scopa-blasts-anti-corruption-task-team-2068219 This is great. It is only when people start picking apart such so-called anti-corruption institutions that they can discover that they are operated for the very purpose of cutting-off or side-lining anti-corruption efforts. While the names of such groups are sober and imposing, they are, under the surface, captive to the same social forces of corruption. It is only by persevering and finding a way to crack the code of corruption, however (the Brazillian model?), that societies will make any progress. It is corruption that is the glue that enables a few bad actors to turn into oppressors of the innocent many.

Cabinet urges creation of new state bank (+1)
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-safrica-zuma-guptas-idUSKCN11817D No racism intended, but the natives are literally going wild! Private bankers had created a corrupt government model with the ANC in power and the Gupta family acting as middle-men. Something has ticked off the bankers (was it corruption so excessive that basic services are in jeopardy?), and they are closing off the financial spigot to both Zuma and the Guptas. The Guptas have gotten the message (or are at least signalling that they have) and have announced their withdrawal. That leaves Zuma and the ANC isolated. Rather than accept the message (dictate), as have the Guptas, and retire peacefully into the sunset, Zuma and the ANC are digging their heels in and fighting on. It's war! "the cabinet also urged Zuma to set up a state bank and called for new banking licenses to be issued to end the "oligopoly" in the industry." Not your ordinary war, mind you. The bankers just want a different corrupt regime. Zuma, demanding to stay, now threatens the corrupt bankers. It's high-level gang war over turf and rent. Usually the money wins, but there's this signal now that Zuma is audacious enough to go after the money. The puppet is threatening to start pulling downward on the strings. Will Zuma follow through on the threat? Could Zuma pull hard enough to pull down the puppet-masters?

‘Futuregrowth decision a vote of no confidence in Zuma’ (+1)
http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/futuregrowth-decision-a-vote-of-no-confidence-in-zuma-2063524 I'm tripped up over proper metaphors, but if it's corruption that maintains illegitimate power, it's debt-based funding which fuels the corruption. It's the new money which greases the cogs of governmental machinery, which is then pilfered by the corrupted. (The thesis being that self-sustaining governments would not be so corrupt.) I have no idea of the significance of Futuregrowth as a funding source, but if they're a major player, this move might signify that the "power behind the power" is withdrawing support for Zuma.

Serious ANC contender steps up (+5)
http://www.dispatchlive.co.za/featured/2016/08/31/gigaba-not-averse-taking-reins-zuma/ It's one thing to have an amorphous notion that "Zuma must go." It's an entirely different notion to have a serious candidate step forward as an alternative. Even if Gigaba is not (really a candidate or) the eventual replacement, there mere contemplation of a concrete alternative crystallizes the possibility of an ANC sans-Zuma as "more real." (I do note that the reporter has more-or-less "put words in the mouth" of Gigaba [the article is anti-Zuma propaganda], but that's not what really matters. What matters is if some number of readers take on the (mistaken) impression that Gigaba is a voluntary candidate of sorts. The idea alone (a recognizable name [twistedly] associated with replacement of Zuma), even if not true or forthright, still performs the function. (The emanator of a deceptive signal (the article author) will always have first mover advantage.) And it's not *all* that bad (although it is bad). The author could always plead it was just an enthusiastic misinterpretation of what does seem like legitimate party "concern" by Gigaba.)

There is much muttering in the ANC about Zuma, but many of the mutterers are reluctant to take any action until they are sure lots of other people will support them. What the heck, time to jump in and take a contrarian perspective. We know power never surrenders voluntarily. My forecast is therefore based on the presumption that the ANC power is sufficiently diffused that Zuma himself is not absolutely necessary. Thus, Zuma can be put out and sill preserve ANC power. The following article is my only (slim) basis for this presumption. My reading of it indicates that there may be power centers within the ANC that feel they can negotiate while still holding out the possibility of removal of Zuma as enticement.
http://www.citizen.co.za/1245811/malema-summoned-for-anc-coalition-talks-report/ On a less practical level, the following article seems like it might describe the ideological state-of-mind: "Resolve to overthrow a government." It's an interesting perspective, because many standard authoritarian models do very much indeed portray the only thing required to keep a populace under control as being "provision of government services." That is, you can get away with a whole lot of corruption if the electricity works, the groceries have food on the shelves, the cops chase burglars, the water flows, and the entertainment venues function. Here, however, this basic "how to" model for tyrants seems to be breaking down, so the ANC is either doing something wrong on the services side or there is a sort of enlightenment afoot. In either case, the ANC would be under pressure.
http://www.iol.co.za/mercury/people-want-more-than-just-things-from-government-2055473

In a public discussion last night - 13 Jun 2016 - professor Chris Landsberg indicated that "it looks increasingly like we should be asking not if but when Zuma's term will end prematurely".  Chris Landsberg is Director: Centre for Policy Studies at the University of Johannesburg. He was speaking at the launch of Adekeye Adebajo's Thabo Mbeki: Africa's Philosopher-King hosted by the Centre for Conflict Resolution. Zuma's term is set to end in 2019 when we (are scheduled to) go to the polls again for a general election. This is Zuma's second term. There are constitutional term limits which preclude him from serving a third term. It is probable that the Zuma presidency will be brought to and end by a decision by the ruling ANC to 'recall' and replace him (as happened in 2008 when Thabo Mbeki was replaced by Kgalema Motlanthe who served until the 2014 general election). We (South Africans) elect a parliament which then chooses a president. So, in effect, the ruling party decides who is to be president. The ANC is the dominant party and, by convention, its president becomes the country's president. The fiction in the ANC is that one does not openly campaign for office but one is deployed at the wish of the party faithful.  The idea that Zuma will flee is unlikely. The current corruption allegations relate to the notion of State Capture and in particular, the involvement of the Indian immigrant Gupta family in various murky transactions. In addition, Zuma may be charged with corruption related to the earlier arms deal. The opposition is pursuing the reinstatement of 783 charges in this regard. If prosecutors are forced to proceed with these charges, the risk of flight may increase but it is currently an unlikely prospect.

We have Local Government elections on 3 Aug 2016. The ANC are likely to maintain a public facade of unity until then, despite the rumours and leaks that abound.
If they perform poorly in the elections - ANC are expected to lose significant ground in metropolitan areas and the opposition has reasonable to good prospects in 3 Metros (NMB - Nelson Mandela Bay [formerly Port Elizabeth] Johannesburg and Tshwane [formerly Pretoria]; in addition, the opposition will retain control of Cape Town) - the ANC may reassess their leadership and 'recall' Zuma (as they did with Thabo Mbeki in 2008).

rawl broke out in the South African parliament on Wednesday after security officers were ordered to forcibly remove opposition MPs from the chamber.
Several punches were thrown as members of the left-wing Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) were expelled for heckling President Jacob Zuma.
It was Mr Zuma's first appearance in parliament since two damning court rulings against him.
On Friday, a court said that Mr Zuma should be charged with corruption.

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/29/jacob-zuma-corruption-charges-review-south-africa-high-court Ok, This doesn't mean the 800 charges will be reinstated, because that decision is up to the  national prosecuting authority. I think it depends on them and I don't know where they stand. It's obvious there is a very real effort to get rid of Zuma, so I'm thinking that this is a real possibility.

The High Court in South Africa suspended a previous ruling which suspended and removed 743 accounts of corruption & fraud prior to becoming president of SA.  It will remain to be seen whether the Democratic Alliance will continue to push for these charges to be brought to the court for conviction.   However, as usual, Zuma will evade and influence the judicial system (as he always has) and remain in office through coercion, party violence, ideological unity, and demonization of opposition parties,  The ANC considers itself above the law and the constitution and has been stated by Zuma as party first!  A further weakening of governance in the country will being society to a point of rupture as it continues its daily demonstrations, riots and demands for Zuma to leave the office of the president.    This slippery character has been able to avert all forms of discipline, rule of law and effective governance and will (sadly) remain to finish his term in 2019.

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36169594
Not what you'd call good news for Zuma, but (a) nothing may come of it, and (b) if anything does, it will grind on for a long time.

Zuma is representative of a strand of thinking within the ANC, and he still has support here (although it has lessened)
The ANC itself is trying to weather a financial and political crisis and wants to demonstrate unity (although this is also an argument for the other side; take away 'unity' and add 'completence' or somesuch)
Zuma is being advised by and siding with other international factions e.g. BRICS; it's in their interest to maintain this influence (e.g. Russian nuclear power stations deal, etc.)
South Africans are increasingly sceptical of the ANC, but there's more scepticism of 'the West', 'neoliberalism', 'white capital' and a combination of other factors that suggest that international perceptions of the country's politics may be coloured more by international and/or market frameworks than perceived political reality in South Africans. As alluded to above though; there is a chance this could happen for various reasons - ANC need to demonstrate competence and existence of counterfactions in the party; increasing influence of Democratic Alliance (opposition party with liberal and pro-Western outlook, financial resources), international political and financial pressures, Zuma's personal stamina/ability to sustain performance running out, decreasing influence of aforesaid allies (e.g. BRICS).

The elections cycle is every five year, and the last elections for the president took place in 2014 - thus the next elections is theoretically speaking only in 2019. Thus, by December 31 2016 Zuma will still be president of SA.
I really hope so , he should have not been the president in the first place .
Knows where the bodies are burief

Strong civil society, self-interest of ANC to remain party of power, ongoing protests and attempts to remove, support of some corrupted elites, but lacks broad support elsewhere, opposition of SANDFU means that use of the military to stay in power would be problematic.  Possible reveals from Panama Papers.
The ANC will want to avoid a conflict situation. If Jacob Zuma keeps to the party line he will serve the rest of his team (only another three years left).

Mr Zuma due to step down as ANC leader in December 2017 and as president after general elections in 2019, he intends to back Ms Dlamini-Zuma as his successor in the hope that she will shield him from any further corruption investigations.
Some analysts believe that with Mr Zuma coming under pressure on various fronts, it is a matter of time before he is is forced to step down.

I very much doubt that he will go voluntarily.

municipal elections loss will precipitate a harder ANC line against the zulu faction- currently I believe he is negotiating a pardon in exchange for a step down - what may keep him in place is the threat of prosecution

The ANC can't depose Zuma as president of South Africa, but they can depose him as the president of the ANC. I think is unlikely because it would show weakness within the ANC. What is more likely is that Zuma will step down due to "health issues" at which point the ANC will appoint someone else in his place.
He is just too powerful, and too corrupt. Not a chance. And he is afraid of prosecution in the courts.

The ANC is the one who will decide if Zuma stays or goes. Untill now  Zuma is still an Asset and there is not a clear challenger within the party. The problem inmSouth Africa is a lack of leadesrhip. If there was a strong leader tomreplace Zuma the change woukd already happened. The will put himmdown eventually but will have a hard time deciding who will replace him.
He is chosen by the majority, so no reason to resign.

He has a lot of people support and a very strong willed leader.
He certainly is not going to quit either.
The ANC hates to admit a mistake.

There are enough mature, calculating politicians who have grown out of viewing the ANC's leader as the rightful rule in South Africa nowadays to engineer this somehow. My guess would be that they 'd come up with a very plausible health reason for Mr. Zuma's departure. Or he might even step down for a legitimate health reason.

The ANC is generally quite a well-disciplined organisation who's historical tendency in a situation like this is to tough it out. In normal times, Zuma would then leave at the party's convention in 2017 to make way for his successor; so that the new party president could become the president of South Africa in the elections of 2019.  These aren't normal times, however, and there is an unusual degree of open resistance to Zuma. This makes an early exit, possible. I think those who would like to replace Zuma may get their chance after the local elections in August this year. It's hard to see the ANC doing well. Aside from the likelihood that they will lose the province at the centre of SA's economy - Gauteng; they are also likely to lose the symbolically important city of Port Elizabeth. They lost the latter in 2014 but it didn't matter (in a sense) because 2014 was a general and not a local election. And they only got 52% in Gauteng. If he does go, then they will find a way to make it look like retirement. It is hard to see him losing as a result of an open revolt.
Although considered corrupt, he is too powerful in the ANC and the ANC is too powerful.

Leaders in souther Africa typically stay for 10-15 years Zuma has been there for 7, which is high for South Africa but low for that part of Africa. This would lead to a small base rate. Question is maybe really how would ANC do in municipal elections? ANC vote is trending down
If Rouseff goes in Brazil, chances for Zuma going as well zoom to 99%!
Easy to draw comparisons with Mkebi but unlikely, despite set backs, in this period.
Going below consensus to start as think its unlikely he will go voluntarily, and if not the process to get rid of him will be long - Think Mugabe!

There is no question that Zuma has substantial political power and HAS HAD the support of many of the core National Executive Council (96 members), many of whom were appointed by him or elected by his help. But money talks.........The Rand continues to plummet. It is a floating exchange currency. There is no restriction on anyone outside of SA in partaking in currency futures, etc. There are increasing risks of a devaluation of SA credit rating. The sacking of the well-respected finance minister has been another catalyst for the Rand's plummet and international disbelief in SA's future with Zuma at the lead. http://qz.com/596693/how-to-explain-why-the-south-african-rand-keeps-falling/ Politically, the very-well-connected Gupta family has been a long-time patron/ally of Zuma, but the Gupta family has to start feeling the heat. Several major firms have cut ties with the Guptas, saying the association is too risky.  The South African branch of global accounting firm KPMG, Barclays Africa and investment bank Sasfin have all announced they will no longer do business with one of the Gupta family companies, Reuters reported. This is definitely a shot across the bow. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/05/firms-cut-ties-jacob-zuma-allies-before-impeachment-vote Despite the recent 233-143 vote against impeachment, increasing numbers of ANC members are gravitating to ANC youth leader Julius Malema. It looks to me that the ANC core member's don't want to give up their power and  privileges, but they need to find a way to make the transition to a new leader. Politics on the ground (based on populous anger, well-established and long-based SA freedom fighters, almost exponential decline in living standards) is the continuing fire that is forcing the turmoil and the need to leap to another leader. Eight months in politics is a long time. Zuma will need to take some early-out offering rather than try to fight to the bitter end that leaves him much less.

The man is made of Teflon, I didn't think he would survive the impeachment process, yet he was never in danger. I wish the other BRICS would take a stronger stance against him and Rousseff, we don't need leaders who run their nations into the ground.
He will probably be replaced as ANC president in 2017. At that point, the ANC may find a way to remove him from national office. But I can't see Pres. Zuma going anywhere before then. Unless he dies.
Who and how will he be replaced?  Not voluntarily and therefore extremely unlikely.
Too entrenched, too rich, too many toadies benefit from his magnificence...
Zuma won't go out unless it's in a coffin. South Africa is failing, but since when did that matter? Big corrupt guys in countries in turmoil tend to win.

I guess Zuma could die of natural causes, but I'd be shocked if he resigned, even if the ANC get absolute whacked in the August local elections. He's a classic Big Man of Sub-Saharan African politics, & the base rate of those guys voluntarily resigning is so low.  plus, the ANC have a leadership election scheduled for 2017 anyway, so it seems pretty logical for him to cling on until then, where the party can just elect someone else if they feel the need.

He's not going to go voluntarily, and though he's been violating or at least bending the rules, calls for him to go have come mostly from the affluent or some of the middle classes, not core ANC supporters that make up the bulk of his electorate. Unless a credible and popular alternative emerges from within the ANC, he will still be President just over 8 months from now.
To be above consensus. If the time period were longer, I'd be higher.

You can tell a lot about a country by whether questions like this include the phrase "flees the capital". But despite all the vivid scenarios I can imagine that lead to a Zuma resignation, the man is *tenacious*, and in the face of pressures that would end most Western politicians. My naive prediction matches the crowd pretty well, so I'll stick with 6 for now.

Initial forecast. Yes, everyone is tired of Jacob, but he really likes being the President.  A waning empire thanks to his benighted rule, but he is a President nonetheless.  By the way, administrator,  I like the clarified rules with respect to any disappearance by Zuma and the declaration of a waiting period. Should cut down on arguments regarding resolution.
Folks, including the ANC, are pretty tired of him, but there is no clear alternative available.  Yet.  Stay tuned, but January is probably too soon.

Several factors can provide some indication of the strength or weakness of the cessation of his presidency; the upcoming municipal elections in August, potential national conventions within the ANC and how they approach the current economic and political crisis (a potent combination for sure of inevitable decline,  downgraded ratings into junk bond status for South Africa (expected to occur as the political and economic crisis deepens (including low growth projections - around 0.8% for 2016 and increasing inflation, volatility within civil society regarding the constitutional court's determination regarding violations of the constitution by both Parliament the Executive,  current mobilization within civil society to perpetually engage in protest within the country if Zuma does not resign (with the ANC-NEC currently supporting a call for him to remain and calling for unity within the party while describing the crisis as an 'imperialist plot'); an increase in the deep divide between intraparty factionalism and interparty factionalism and mass mobilization by workers, students, religious leaders, and the potential to creating a network within the international community to apply sanctions related activism and legislation aimed at stabilizing the country (destabilization seem as Zuma's continued hold on the executive and the apparatus of the state.  Additional motivating factors are the number of daily protests, strikes and violence events within civil society toward political parties (ie., members) and the state, including factionalism in general.   Estimates are projected to change with rapid pace as economic and political develops within the country.

Starting low based upon my first and hard-learned rule of sitting heads of state: they don't go easy.  That said, this disenchantment with Zuma has been building for a bit, so there is real possibility he will not last out his term. But in the short run -- and to me 1-1-2017 is the short run -- he will survive.   General interest profile of Zuma. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-17450447
